Months later, it emerged from Cora that Tanya had to be committed to a psychiatric hospital because of the increasing trauma of losing Abi. ==Creation== ===Casting=== In early reports of the character's arrival, her name was spelt ''Tania''. This was later changed on the official BBC website.{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/catchall/tm_method=full%26objectid=16930190%26siteid=89520-name_page.html|title=EXCLUSIVE: NO ANGEL JO OFF TO ALBERT SQ|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|first=Nicola|last=Methven|date=11 April 2006|accessdate=13 July 2009}}{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/a31521/joyner-joins-eastenders.html|title=Joyner joins 'EastEnders'|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|first=Kris|last=Green|date=11 April 2006|accessdate=13 July 2009}}{{cite interview| last = Joyner | first = Jo| subjectlink = Jo Joyner| interviewer = [[Richard and Judy|Richard Madeley and Judy Finnigan]]| work = [[Richard & Judy]]| date = 26 February 2007 }} Joyner originally turned down the role as she had doubts over whether she could work in a soap opera.{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/a58037/eastenders-star-joyner-turned-down-role.html|title='EastEnders' star Joyner turned down role|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|first=Daniel|last=Kilkelly|date=20 May 2007|accessdate=13 July 2009}} She said "It was a massive decision. I said no originally. Playing someone in a soap is a big responsibility. People are very protective of the soap and if you are rubbish you can't get away from it." Also, having worked quietly and successfully in the industry for eight years, Joyner was unsure if she would be comfortable with the level of fame being on ''EastEnders'' would bring her. During the affair storyline between [[Stacey Slater]] ([[Lacey Turner]]) and Tanya's husband [[Max Branning|Max]] ([[Jake Wood]]), Joyner did not read any parts of the ''EastEnders'' scripts other than her own, as she felt her acting was improved by not knowing what Max did behind Tanya's back, and because she felt that she could better justify to herself why Tanya would not suspect Max of cheating if she in reality did not know what he was getting up to. ===Characterisation=== {{Quote box|quote="I have to say actually, I do prefer playing a sort of tarty, nasty bitch, because quite frankly it's more fun. I do love playing Tanya, but it is very different to the roles I had before EastEnders. I'd like to see a bit more of her feisty side."|source=—Jo Joyner{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title='Enders Jo Joyner wants "feisty" Tanya|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a208756/enders-jo-joyner-wants-feisty-tanya.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=17 July 2011|date=2010-03-15}}|width=30%|align=right}} In a July 2008 interview with the ''[[Sunday People]]'', Joyner revealed that she was disappointed that Tanya's wild child past had not been explored more in the aftermath of her character burying Max alive, saying "I didn't think Tanya would be as mumsy at first. She was quite hard in her past and it would have been fun to have that side come out. Tanya has a really naughty side. When she was young she was a lot like Stacey Slater. That hasn't really come out yet but she definitely has it in her."{{cite news|url=http://www.people.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/2008/07/27/i-wish-they-d-let-me-be-a-wild-child-102039-20672545/|title=I WISH THEY'D LET ME BE A WILD CHILD |publisher=[[The People]]|first=Wise|last=Jon|date=27 July 2008|accessdate=15 April 2011}} Joyner temporarily left the show in December 2009 for maternity leave.{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/a164837/eastenders-star-pregnant-with-twins.html|title='EastEnders' star pregnant with twins|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|first=Kris|last=Green|date=13 July 2009|accessdate=13 July 2009}} Her departure was facilitated through a storyline in which Max hid financial problems from the family and Tanya left him. The show's executive producer [[Diederick Santer]] revealed that some planned storyline material for Max and Tanya was put on hold until Joyner's return from maternity leave.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a189593/producers-perspective-2009-diederick-santer.html|title=Producer's Perspective 2009: Diederick Santer|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|first=Kris|last=Green|date=17 December 2009|accessdate=17 December 2009}} On 6 May 2010, Joyner filmed a single episode that was broadcast on 23 June,{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/scoop/a218713/first-pic-jo-joyner-returns-to-eastenders.html|title=First Pic: Jo Joyner returns to 'EastEnders'|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|first=Kris|last=Green|date=7 May 2010|accessdate=7 May 2010}} and she made her full-time return on 27 September 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00tz282|title=EastEnders 27/09/2010|publisher=[[BBC Programmes]]|accessdate=20 September 2010}} {{cquote|Family is paramount to Tanya. Max was the love of her life, but his affair with Stacey destroyed their marriage, and nearly destroyed her. Though she's had dalliances with Sean Slater, Jack Branning and even went up the aisle with Greg Jessop, it's Max she always goes back to. Tanya may be one of Walford's most loving mums, but she also has a wild side. So she's wise to any and all of the tricks pulled by her rebellious daughter, Lauren – she pulled them herself when she was the same age.|4=Description of Tanya on the BBC Website (2012){{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/eastenders/characters/tanya=branning.shtml|title=Tanya Cross (Jo Joyner)|year=2012|work=EastEnders|publisher=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=22 January 2013}}}} In an interview with ''[[Digital Spy]]'', Joyner admitted that she prefers playing a "feisty" character and would like to explore that side of Tanya. Joyner confirmed that she wants sparks to fly between her character and estranged husband Max. She added: "I hope it comes out. I think she's been a little bit calm and a little bit mumsy lately and I think if she's been away from Max for a while, she needs to come back with a bit more fight about her and have him on his knees a bit." Of her experiences as a mother, she added: "It's fantastic. It's full on but it's just been a whirlwind. I've just been so lucky." ==Development== On 21 March 2008, Joyner revealed a script in which Tanya would bury Max alive. Speaking of when she first heard about the burial idea, the actress admitted: "I actually was really upset! I heard about the theory and I thought 'how are you going to get me there? She's not a killer!" "I did always say to Diederick [Santer] when this happened that as far as I was concerned, the only way she can kill Max is when she finds out on Christmas Eve in a blind fit of rage – that's the only time when she could be a murderer."{{cite web|last=Green|first=Kris|title=Walford's Jo Joyner reveals burial script shock|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a92072/walfords-jo-joyner-reveals-burial-script-shock.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=17 July 2011|date=2008-03-21}} In February 2011, it was announced that filming had started on location for Greg and Tanya's wedding in April 2011. However, at the time it was unconfirmed whether they would actually marry, meaning that the couple's future would hang in the balance until the time of broadcast.{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a305197/eastenders-cast-film-wedding-scenes.html|title='EastEnders' cast film wedding scenes|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=22 February 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=22 February 2011|location=London}} The ''[[Daily Mail]]'' reported that Tanya would flee the wedding to help Max and Abi when they are hurt in a serious accident,{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a307517/eastenders-films-car-crash-scenes.html|title='EastEnders' films car crash scenes|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=7 March 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=7 March 2011|location=London}} though they said that Tanya and Greg may have already exchanged vows.{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a305456/wedding-day-shock-for-enders-tanya.html|title=Wedding day shock for 'Enders Tanya|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=23 February 2011|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=23 February 2011|location=London}} Joyner revealed to ''[[What's on TV]]'' that she thinks that happy storylines are boring and that ''EastEnders'' needs depressing storylines to be dramatic.{{cite web|last=Millar|first=Paul|title='EastEnders' wouldn't be fun without misery, says Jo Joyner|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a371196/eastenders-wouldnt-be-fun-without-misery-says-jo-joyner.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines]]|accessdate=4 April 2012|date=14 March 2012}} She added that Walford is a miserable place which part of the fun. ===Cervical cancer=== On 26 June 2011, it was announced by ''EastEnders'' that Tanya will feature in a cervical cancer storyline.{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title='EastEnders' confirms cervical cancer storyline|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a326847/eastenders-confirms-cervical-cancer-storyline.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=London: [[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=8 January 2012|date=2011-06-25}} Executive producer Bryan Kirkwood said that viewers will see Tanya receive the devastating news that she has cervical cancer. EastEnders has worked closely with experts in the field to ensure that the issue is accurately portrayed. Viewers will see how Tanya, a mother of three, will use her inner determination to deal with what will be one of the toughest challenges of her life. The director of Jo's Cervical Cancer trust Robert Music said that ''EastEnders'' must depict the disease accurately and responsibly saying "It's about educating the general public who perhaps aren't aware of the disease, but also with cervical cancer, there are thousands of women out there who have been diagnosed or are living with this." Music of added: "As the UK's only charity solely dedicated to informing and supporting women affected by cervical abnormalities and cervical cancer, we think it is fantastic that EastEnders has decided to highlight the issue of cervical cancer." "This is a disease that affects thousands of women and their loved ones in the UK every year, and for many can be preventable by taking proactive steps, such as attending cervical screening when invited." Music added: "EastEnders have gone to great lengths to research this story with us and we hope that by showing this storyline to its millions of viewers, it will not only raise awareness of cervical cancer but also help the public to be more informed about this issue." Ellen Lang of ''[[Macmillan Cancer Support]]'' said that cervical cancer is diagnosed in thousands of women every year in the UK, so EastEnders is congratulated for tackling this difficult subject that affects many people. Jo Joyner said that she will make sure that the storyline will be "honest and true to life" as possible.{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title='EastEnders' cancer plot is a responsibility, says Jo Joyner|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a332946/eastenders-cancer-plot-is-a-responsibility-says-jo-joyner.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=London: [[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=8 January 2012|date=2011-08-02}} Talking to ''[[All About Soap]]'' about how she has researched the plot, Joyner said that she has talked to many survivors of cervical cancer through a charity named Jo's Trust and added that they have a great website, which is very informative and has helped her a lot. Joyner said that it is a privilege to be given any sort of serious storyline and a real responsibility. Asked whether it makes Tanya think twice who she wants to be with, Joyner replied: "Definitely. She remembers her mum looking at her dad with pity [when he was ill] and she'd hate that happening to her. She has some serious thinking to do about her future now." Jo's Cervical Cancer Trust has praised ''EastEnders'' for helping spread the awareness of cervical cancer. The trust received extra calls following Tanya's diagnosis.{{cite web|last=Eames|first=Tom|title='EastEnders' Tanya storyline praised by cancer charity|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a336744/eastenders-tanya-storyline-praised-by-cancer-charity.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=London: [[Hachette Filipacchi UK]]|accessdate=8 January 2012|date=2011-08-23}} Kirkwood said in a news release that EastEnders worked closely with experts to ensure that the issue is accurately portrayed and that viewers will see how Tanya will use her inner determination to deal with what will be one of the toughest challenges of her life. Music said that Joyner was "fantastic" when visiting the charity. He added that she was "really hungry to learn, to understand what the impact was, and she felt a responsibility to get this right" Joyner stated that she "feels grateful" to be in a cervical cancer storyline. She told ''Soaplife'' magazine: "It's a privilege to be given any sort of serious storyline and a real responsibility. I'm going to make it as honest and true to life as I possibly can. I will grab every chance I can to show Tanya dropping her guard." Speaking of her past, she added:"Tanya remembers her mum looking at her dad with pity and she'd hate that happening to her. Tanya's dad died of cancer and she nursed him through it. She's seen it first hand and therefore has a deep-seated fear of it."{{cite web|last=Millar|first=Paul|title='EastEnders' Jo Joyner 'privileged by cancer storyline'|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a341418/eastenders-jo-joyner-privileged-by-cancer-storyline.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines]]|accessdate=8 January 2012|date=2011-09-20}} Joyner said it's important to keep her cervical cancer storyline as realistic as possible. She said that viewers will see Tanya's appearance change as the storyline progresses.{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title='EastEnders' Tanya will have a slow decline, says Jo Joyner|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a343170/eastenders-tanya-will-have-a-slow-decline-says-jo-joyner.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines]]|accessdate=8 January 2012|date=2011-09-30}} Asked whether Tanya will start to look ill, Joyner said to ''[[Soaplife]]'': "I'd like her to and I made a point of saying, 'Unless we ever see Tanya looking tired these references are going to be rubbish', because she's keeping up the pretence and putting on lots of make-up. But I've had my extensions out and the false lashes are coming off. It will be a slow decline." Joyner later said that she does not become depressed over the cancer plot, saying she can switch off from the emotions instantly.{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title='EastEnders' Jo Joyner: 'I don't get depressed over Tanya plot'|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a367175/eastenders-jo-joyner-i-dont-get-depressed-over-tanya-plot.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines]]|accessdate=22 February 2012|date=22 February 2012}} Speaking to the ''[[Daily Star (United Kingdom)|Daily Star]]'', Joyner said that rather than becoming depressed over the scenes, she goes home relieved that it's not her life. She added: "I go home and laugh even more hysterically than I would normally because of what's happening to Tanya. My husband doesn't agree. He thinks I carry it all more than I think I do. He says I come back miserable, but once I've put the kids in the bath and had a laugh, then I feel good again." ===Departure=== On 1 May 2012, it was reported that Joyner would take a prolonged break from the show at the end of her current contract, to spend time with her family, and an inside source stated that she "will definitely return".{{cite web|last=Goodacre|first=Kate|title='EastEnders' Jo Joyner 'to take break from soap in 2013'|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a379257/eastenders-jo-joyner-to-take-break-from-soap-in-2013.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|accessdate=1 May 2012|date=1 May 2012}} Joyner confirmed this herself, saying that the break would last six months, similar to other actors who took breaks in 2012, such as [[June Brown]] ([[Dot Cotton|Dot Branning]]) and [[Charlie Brooks]] ([[Janine Butcher]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a400360/eastenders-jo-joyner-huge-branning-secret-revealed-at-christmas.html |title='EastEnders' Jo Joyner: 'Huge Branning secret revealed at Christmas' |publisher=Digital Spy |date=19 August 2012 |accessdate=15 June 2014}} However, on 1 April 2013, it was announced that Joyner's departure would be indefinite as she wished to try new career paths. Speaking of this, Joyner said, "I love playing Tanya and being part of such a great show, but she has been on quite a rollercoaster over the past seven years and I have come to realise that it's right for her to step away from Walford for a bit longer than originally planned. I have been very fortunate to have been part of some fantastic storylines over the years, and I have worked with some wonderful people during my time on the show which I will always be very grateful for, but I feel that as a mother and an actress it is time for me to explore some other avenues for a while." Executive Producer Lorraine Newman stated that whilst Tanya will be missed, her exit will bring a new era to the Branning family but refused to say how Tanya will leave the show.{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title='EastEnders': Jo Joyner announces departure from show|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a469652/eastenders-jo-joyner-announces-departure-from-show.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|accessdate=1 April 2013|date=1 April 2013}} Joyner filmed her final scenes on 15 May 2013,{{cite news|last1=Kilkelly|first1=Daniel|title='EastEnders': Jo Joyner films final scenes as Tanya Cross|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/eastenders/news/a481677/eastenders-jo-joyner-films-final-scenes-as-tanya-cross/|accessdate=28 December 2017|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|date=15 May 2013}} and Tanya departed the serial on 28 June.{{Fact|date=January 2018}} ===Returns=== In December 2014 it was announced that Tanya would return in February 2015 for a few episodes, for [[Ian Beale]] ([[Adam Woodyatt]]) and [[Jane Beale]]’s ([[Laurie Brett]]) wedding and for the [[EastEnders Live Week|show's 30th anniversary]].{{Cite news|url=http://insidemediatrack.com/2015/01/jo-joyner-set-for-eastenders-return/|title=Jo Joyner set for EastEnders return - Inside Media Track|date=11 January 2015|work=Inside Media Track|access-date=24 January 2018|language=en-GB}} Tanya appears in the episode broadcast on 18 and 19 February. The episodes were shown live, and Joyner accidentally referred to Ian by his actor's name.{{cite news|last1=Fletcher|first1=Harry|title='How's Adam?' Jo Joyner's Tanya Branning in EastEnders live slip-up|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/eastenders/news/a629924/hows-adam-jo-joyners-tanya-branning-in-eastenders-live-slip-up/|accessdate=28 December 2017|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines UK]]|date=18 February 2015}} Joyner made an unannounced return on 25 December 2017 as part of Jossa and Fitzgerald's departures.{{cite news|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2017-12-25/eastenders-tanya-branning-returns-in-shock-twist/|title=EastEnders: Tanya Branning returns in shock twist|work=Radio Times|last=Hughes|first=Jonathon|date=25 December 2017|accessdate=26 December 2017}} [[Simon Ashdown]], who created the character of Tanya, was invited back to write the Christmas Day episode and Joyner was approached by Ashdown and executive consultant, [[John Yorke (producer)|John Yorke]]. Joyner was initially nervous about going back due to her mistake in the live episodes, but knew she had to return when the story was pitched to her. The episodes were mainly filmed at night due to Joyner's other work commitments.{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/eastenders/news/a846163/eastenders-jo-joyner-tanya-christmas-return/|title=EastEnders star was "nervous" about surprise Christmas Day return|work=Digital Spy|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=25 December 2017|accessdate=26 December 2017}} ==Reception== Joyner won the 'Most Popular Actress' award at the [[Digital Spy Soap Awards]] in 2008 for the part of Tanya{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/i126527/jo-joyner.html|title=Digital Spy Soap Awards 2008: Jo Joyner|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=21 March 2008|accessdate=13 July 2009}} and also went on to win 'Best Dramatic Performance' at the 2008 [[British Soap Awards]] and made the final four in the 'Best Actress' category. Joyner was nominated for the "best actress" award at the ''[[All About Soap]]'' Awards in 2012{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title=2012 All About Soap Awards – full nominations list|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/scoop/a365280/2012-all-about-soap-awards-full-nominations-list.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines]]|accessdate=4 April 2012|date=12 February 2012}} and later won the award.{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title=All About Soap Awards 2012: Full winners list|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/scoop/a373014/all-about-soap-awards-2012-full-winners-list.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=[[Hearst Magazines]]|accessdate=4 April 2012|date=25 March 2012}} In 2012, Joyner and Wood won the Best On-Screen Partnership category at the British Soap Awards.{{cite web|author=British Soap Awards |url=http://www.britishsoapawards.tv/winners |title=Winners – British Soap Awards |publisher=Britishsoapawards.tv |date= |accessdate=15 June 2014}} On Digital Spy's 2012 end of year reader poll, Joyner was nominated for "Best Female Soap Actor" and came fourth with 13.4% of the vote.{{cite web|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|title='EastEnders', Corrie, 'Hollyoaks' all win in Digital Spy's 2012 poll|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/soaps/s2/eastenders/news/a446819/eastenders-corrie-hollyoaks-all-win-in-digital-spys-2012-poll.html|work=[[Digital Spy]]|publisher=([[Hearst Magazines UK]])|accessdate=22 December 2012|date=22 December 2012}} The character has been pivotal in the transformation of ''EastEnders''. Christmas Day 2007 saw Tanya discover husband Max and stepdaughter-in-law Stacey's affair and was watched by 14.3 million viewers, making it the highest rated ''EastEnders'' episode in three years and the highest rated television broadcast of 2007.{{cite news|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/news.nsf/story/eastenders-tops-2007-ratings_1056744|title=Eastenders Tops 2007 Ratings|publisher=[[Contactmusic]]|date=18 January 2008|accessdate=12 October 2010}} In March 2008 viewers watched Tanya bury husband Max alive. This was the most watched ''EastEnders'' episode of 2008 and the episode received 116 complaints from viewers.{{cite news|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/broadcasting/s2/eastenders/news/a103137/enders-rapped-over-harrowing-burial.html|title='Enders rapped over "harrowing" burial|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|date=23 June 2008|accessdate=12 October 2010}} The UK communications regulator [[Ofcom]] later found that the episodes depicting the storyline were in breach of the 2005 Broadcasting Code. They contravened the rules regarding protection of children by appropriate scheduling, appropriate depiction of violence before the 9 p.m. watershed and appropriate depiction of potentially offensive content.{{cite web|url=http://www.ofcom.org.uk/tv/obb/prog_cb/obb112/issue112.pdf|title=Ofcom Broadcast Bulletin 112|publisher=[[Ofcom]]|page=Page 17|date=23 June 2008|accessdate=13 July 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326125642/http://www.ofcom.org.uk/tv/obb/prog_cb/obb112/issue112.pdf|archivedate=26 March 2009}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{EastEnders character external link|tanya-branning}} *{{BBC Online|id=programmes/p01c1kf5|title=The Best of Tanya...}} *[http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2013-06-28/eastenders-tanyas-top-10-greatest-moments Tanya's Top 10 Greatest Moments] at ''[[Radio Times]]'' {{EastEnders characters|past}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Branning, Tanya}} [[Category:EastEnders characters]] [[Category:Fictional beauticians]] [[Category:Fictional businesspeople]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2006]] [[Category:Fictional characters with cancer]] [[Category:Female characters in television]]

page.title: The Death of General Warren at the Battle of Bunker's Hill, June 17, 1775

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{for|the battle itself|Battle of Bunker Hill}} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = File:The Death of General Warren at the Battle of Bunker's Hill, June 17, 1775.jpg | painting_alignment = | image_size = 300px | title = ''The Death of General Warren at the Battle of Bunker's Hill, June 17, 1775'' | alt = The painting is fully described in the article text. | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[John Trumbull]] | year = | medium = [[oil on canvas]] | height_metric = 184.2 | width_metric = 274.5 | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Hartford, Connecticut]] | museum = [[Wadsworth Atheneum]] | owner = | italic title = force }} {{Infobox artwork | image_file = The Death of General Warren at the Battle of Bunker's Hill.jpg | painting_alignment = | image_size = 300px | title = ''The Death of General Warren at the Battle of Bunker's Hill, June 17, 1775'' | alt = The painting is fully described in the article text. | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[John Trumbull]] | year = | medium = [[oil on canvas]] | height_metric = 50.16 | width_metric = 75.56 | height_imperial = {{frac|19|3|4}} | width_imperial = {{frac|29|3|4}} | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Boston, Massachusetts]] | museum = [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Museum of Fine Arts]] | owner = | italic title = force }} '''''The Death of General Warren at the Battle of Bunker's Hill, June 17, 1775''''' refers to several [[oil painting|oil paintings]] completed in the early 19th century by the American artist [[John Trumbull]] depicting the death of [[Joseph Warren]] at the June 17, 1775 [[Battle of Bunker Hill]], during the [[American Revolutionary War]]. Warren, an influential [[Massachusetts]] physician and politician, had been commissioned as a general but he served in the battle as a volunteer private. He was killed during or shortly after the storming of the [[redoubt]] atop [[Breed's Hill]] by [[Kingdom of Great Britain|British]] troops.
The paintings are iconic images of the American Revolution. Trumbull painted several versions, including the one held by the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]] (dated between 1815 and 1831). This was commissioned by the Warren family and passed down through the family before being acquired by the museum.<ref>[http://www.mfa.org/collections/object/the-death-of-general-warren-at-the-battle-of-bunker-s-hill-17-june-1775-34260], ''[[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]]''</ref> Another, larger version (dated 1834) is held by the [[Wadsworth Atheneum]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut]].<ref>[http://www.pubhist.com/w13399]</ref> Trumbull sold the engraving rights for both this painting and ''[[The Death of General Montgomery in the Attack on Quebec, December 31, 1775]],'' which resulted in a highly successful subscription release that greatly enhanced his career.
==Event== Artist [[John Trumbull]] (1756–1843) was in the colonial army camp at [[Roxbury, Massachusetts]] on June 17, 1775, the day of the [[Battle of Bunker Hill]]. He watched the battle unfold through field glasses, and later decided to depict one of its central events.<ref name=T137>Tamarkin, p. 137</ref> [[Joseph Warren]], a [[Massachusetts]] politician and member of the colony's [[Committee of Safety (American Revolution)|Committee of Safety]], volunteered to serve under Colonel [[William Prescott]] in the defense of the [[redoubt]] which the colonists had constructed on top of [[Breed's Hill]]. This redoubt was the target of three British attacks, of which the first two were repulsed. The third attack succeeded, in part because the defenders had run out of ammunition. Warren was struck by a musket or pistol ball during the evacuation of the redoubt, and killed instantly.
==Description== [[File:Self Portrait by John Trumbull circa 1802.jpeg|thumb|left|upright=0.9|Self-portrait of Trumbull]] The central focus of the painting is Warren's body, dressed in white, and [[John Small (British Army officer)|John Small]], a British major, dressed in a scarlet uniform (holding a sword in his left hand).<ref name="Key to the Battle of Bunker's Hill">{{cite web|title=Key to the Battle of Bunker's Hill|url=http://www.americanrevolution.org/bunkey.html|publisher=americanrevolution.org|accessdate=13 July 2012}}</ref> Small, who had served with colonial general [[Israel Putnam]] during the [[French and Indian War]], is shown preventing a fellow British soldier from bayoneting Warren. Trumbull wanted to express the poignancy in the conflict of men who had earlier served together.
On the far right of the painting is a colonial officer, [[Thomas Grosvenor (American Revolution)|Thomas Grosvenor]], with a black man holding a [[musket]] behind him. The black man was long thought to be [[Peter Salem]], a freed slave who served in the cause of American independence. Later research identified him as a slave belonging to Grosvenor.<ref name=T137/>
The foreground is littered with bodies from both sides of the conflict, and the background includes clusters of colonial and British troops carrying flags. [[Boston Harbor]] is also visible in the distance. The sky is partially obscured by smoke rising from [[Charlestown, Massachusetts|Charlestown]], which had been torched by the British.
In describing the painting for a catalogue of his works, Trumbull explained why he chose to emphasize the British Major Small's role, saying that Small, whom he had met in London, "was equally distinguished by acts of humanity and kindness to his enemies, as by bravery and fidelity to the cause he served."<ref>Tamarkin, p. 134</ref>
==People depicted== {{Expand list|date=February 2011}} {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage=[[File:AttackBunkerHill.jpg|210px]] | video1 = [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DkVDDn8ghKk Lecture 8, ''John Trumbull and Historical Fiction: The Battle of Bunker's Hill, June 17, 1775 (1786)''], 56 minutes, Yale University Courses, [[Yale University]]}}
===British soldiers=== *Major [[John Small (British Army officer)|John Small]], the redcoated British soldier stepping over a fallen redcoat soldier to hold back the bayonet of a fellow soldier *Major [[John Pitcairn]], falling back dying in his son's (Lieutenant Pitcairn's) arms *General [[Henry Clinton (American War of Independence)|Henry Clinton]], bare-headed British officer with raised sword at the rear, center of the painting * General [[William Howe, 5th Viscount Howe|William Howe]], standing to the left of Clinton from the viewer's point of view with his sword pointing forward. *[[Francis Rawdon-Hastings, 1st Marquess of Hastings|Lord Rawdon]] holds the British [[ensign]], center-right in the painting
===Colonists=== *[[Joseph Warren]] *[[Thomas Grosvenor (American Revolution)|Thomas Grosvenor]], soldier to the far right *An African-American slave of Grosvenor, shown behind the officer <ref name=T137/> *Major [[Andrew McClary]]<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Library of Congress |title=The Battle of Bunker's Hill, June 17th 1775 |accessdate=May 9, 2016 |url=https://www.loc.gov/item/2014645332/ |ref=LOC}}</ref> *A black freeman, possibly [[Peter Salem]], head visible below the flags on the left side of the painting *General [[Israel Putnam]], colonial officer on the far left of the painting *[[Thomas Knowlton]], standing over Warren and holding a musket *Lieutenant-Colonel Moses Parker of [[Chelmsford, Massachusetts|Chelmsford]] is depicted sitting wounded to the left of Warren <!-- Parker was shot in the leg, taken prisoner, had his leg amputated, and died as a prisoner in Boston on July 4, 1775. --> *Colonel [[Thomas Gardner]] lying on ground lower right.<ref>''Sons of the American Revolution Magazine'', Jan. 1969</ref> Both Gardner and Parker were taken prisoner, and both died in early July in Boston.
==References== ;Notes {{reflist}}
;Sources {{refbegin}} *{{cite book|title=Anglophilia: deference, devotion, and antebellum America|first=Elisa|last=Tamarkin|isbn=978-0-226-78944-6|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=2008}} *Masur, Louis P. "Pictures Have Now Become a Necessity": The Use of Images in American History Textbooks." The Journal of American History, March 1998, pp. 1409–24. {{refend}}
==External links== *[http://www.derekbeck.com/1775/info/death-of-warren/ Blog on the forensics of Warren's death]
{{John Trumbull}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Death Of General Warren At The Battle Of Bunker Hill, The}} [[Category:Paintings about the American Revolution]] [[Category:1786 paintings]] [[Category:Massachusetts in the American Revolution]] [[Category:Paintings by John Trumbull]] [[Category:War paintings]] [[Category:Flags in art]]

revision.comment: the work's name is "The New York Times"
revision.text:
{{italictitle}} '''''The Fiction Circus''''' is a [[Brooklyn, NY|Brooklyn-]] and [[Austin, TX|Austin-based]] online [[literary magazine]] and [[art collective]] that publishes short fiction and essays on the arts. The group also holds staged [[multimedia]] fiction readings accompanied by [[electronic music]] and incorporating visual art and theater as a [[frame narrative]]. The writers of the site operate under names such as Miracle Jones, Stephen Future, Geoff Sebesta, Goodman Carter, and Xerxes Verdammt, and the main magazine content includes writing about classical and contemporary literature, including fiction in non-traditional media.
''The Fiction Circus'' has been featured in ''[[Slashdot]]'',<ref>Lord, Timothy. [http://news.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=09/04/28/1613214 "Google To Remove "Inappropriate" Books From Digital Library."] April 28, 2009.</ref> ''[[The New York Times]]''<ref>Bleyer, Jennifer. [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/20/nyregion/thecity/20yipp.html?_r=1 "At the Yippie Museum, It's Parrots and Flannel."]. January 20, 2008.</ref> and ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'',<ref>Sterling, Bruce. [https://www.wired.com/beyond_the_beyond/2009/08/text-to-movies "Text-to-movies."]. August 7, 2009.</ref> among other online news sources. They have performed throughout [[New York City]] and [[Austin, Texas]], including [[KGB (bar)|The KGB Bar]] and the [[Yippie Museum/Café|Yippie Museum & Café]].
''Fiction Circus'' live shows have been reviewed in ''[[The Huffington Post]]''<ref>Herz, Christopher. [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/christopher-herz/the-circus-is-in-town_b_653596.html "The Circus Is in Town!"]. July 21, 2010.</ref> and in ''[[The New York Observer]]''.<ref>Freeman, Nate. [http://www.observer.com/2010/culture/summoning-f-scott-east-village "What F. Scott Fitzgerald Wants Us to Know."]. August 30, 2010.</ref>

{{Infobox book |name = The Ominous Parallels |image = The Ominous Parallels.jpg |caption = Cover of the first edition |author = [[Leonard Peikoff]] |cover_artist = C. Lichty |country = United States |language = English |series = Ayn Rand Library |subjects = [[Nazi Germany]]
[[Politics of the United States]] |pub_date = 1982 |publisher = [[Stein and Day]] |media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]] and [[Paperback]]) |pages = 383 |isbn = 0-8128-2850-X |oclc = 488363398 }} '''''The Ominous Parallels: The End of Freedom in America''''' is a 1982 book by philosopher [[Leonard Peikoff]], in which the author compares the culture of the [[United States]] with the culture of [[Germany]] leading up to the Nazis. The book has an introduction by [[Ayn Rand]], who describes it as "the first book by an Objectivist philosopher other than myself". Rand credited Peikoff with identifying "the cause of [[Nazism]]—and the ominous parallels between the intellectual history of Germany and of the United States".[[#Ran82|Rand 1982. pp. vii–viii.]] ==Publishing history== The hardcover first edition was published by [[Stein and Day]] in 1982. A paperback edition was published by [[New American Library]] in 1983.{{harvnb|Perinn|1990|p=53}} In 2013, parts of ''The Ominous Parallels'' were republished in a new work by Peikoff, ''The Cause of Hitler's Germany''.[[#Pei13|Peikoff 2013]]. ==Reception== German expatriate [[Hiltgunt Zassenhaus]] gave the book a positive review, saying it showed the importance of working to build a free society.{{harvnb|Zassenhaus|1982}} In a ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' profile of Peikoff, Rogers Worthington called it "a fascinating weave of German history, philosophic determinism, and Objectivist polemic".{{harvnb|Worthington|1982|p=3.1}} The reviewer for ''[[The Indianapolis Star]]'' found Peikoff's description of the parallels interesting, but was disappointed that his proposed remedy was Rand's [[Objectivism (Ayn Rand)|Objectivist philosophy]].{{harvnb|Cole|1982}} ==References== ===Footnotes=== {{reflist|20em}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} * {{Cite news |ref=harv |first=Ben {{Infobox book| <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = The Rationalists | title_orig = | translator = | image = The Rationalists.jpg| author = [[John Cottingham]] | cover_artist = | country = Great Britain | language = English | series = | genre = [[History of Philosophy]] | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | release_date = 1988 | media_type = | pages = 244 | isbn = 0-19-289190-1 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
'''''The Rationalists''''' is a 1988 book by [[John Cottingham]]. It offers an overview of the most important exponents of [[rationalism]], namely [[Descartes]], [[Spinoza]] and [[Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz|Leibniz]]. Other thinkers, such as [[Nicolas Malebranche|Malebranche]], are dealt with, too.
==External links== *[https://www.amazon.com/Rationalists-History-Western-Philosophy/dp/0192891901 Reviews]
